algorithm_technique: Breadth-First Search (BFS) to find connected components of fish.
Depth-First Search (DFS) to find connected components of fish.
problem_summary_simple: Find the largest connected area of fish in a grid.
problem_summary_technical: Graph traversal (BFS or DFS) to identify and sum fish in connected water cells, marking visited cells.
key_insights: Each connected component of water cells represents a single catchable school of fish.
BFS is suitable for exploring connected components level by level.
Modifying the grid in-place (setting visited cells to 0) prevents recounting.
DFS is also effective for exploring connected components recursively or iteratively.
The maximum number of fish is the maximum sum found across all connected components.
The grid dimensions are small (10x10), making O(m*n) space for DFS stack acceptable.
